pt: {sc}delusion{/sc} {sc}illusion{/sc} {sc}hallucination{/sc} {sc}mirage{/sc} mean something that is believed to be true or real but that is actually false or unreal. {sc}delusion{/sc} implies an inability to distinguish between what is real and what only seems to be real, often as the result of a disordered state of mind.
{sc}illusion{/sc} implies a false ascribing of reality based on what one sees or imagines.
{sc}hallucination{/sc} implies impressions that are the product of disordered senses, as because of mental illness or drugs.
{sc}mirage{/sc} in its extended sense applies to an illusory vision, dream, hope, or aim.

pt.t: claimed a balanced budget is a {it}mirage{/it}

et: Middle English, from Late Latin {it}delusion-, delusio{/it}, from {it}deludere{/it} {dx_ety}see {dxt|delude||}{/dx_ety}

a delusion that one has concerning oneself
